Heading.TitleText: Passenger Cars, Multi-purpose Passenger Vehicles, Trucks, Trailers and Buses

Subsection.Text: Every passenger car, multi-purpose passenger vehicle, truck, trailer and bus shall conform to Technical Standards Document No. 108, Lamps, Reflective Devices, and Associated Equipment (TSD 108), as amended from time to time.
Every three-wheeled vehicle shall be equipped with lamps, reflex reflectors and associated components as required under subsection (1) for passenger cars, and

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if an outermost parking lamp is installed more than 400 mm from the nearest of the two outer edges of the vehicle that are used to determine the overall width of the vehicle, with a white forward-facing reflex reflector that is installed not more than 400 mm from that edge to indicate the width of the vehicle; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if an outermost tail lamp or outermost rear reflex reflector is installed more than 400 mm from the nearest of the two outer edges of the vehicle that are used to determine the overall width of the vehicle, with a red rearward-facing reflex reflector that is installed not more than 400 mm from that edge to indicate the width of the vehicle.

Heading.TitleText: Alternative Lamps for Passenger Cars, Three-wheeled Vehicles, Multi-purpose Passenger Vehicles, Trucks and Buses

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (4), instead of being equipped with headlamps as required under subsection (1) or (2), as the case may be, passenger cars, three-wheeled vehicles, multi-purpose passenger vehicles, trucks and buses may be equipped with adaptive driving beam lamps that conform to SAE Recommended Practice J3069, Adaptive Driving Beam (June 2016), except that the lamps shall not be capable of activation or deactivation by pedal.

If the adaptive driving beam is formed by the entirety or a portion of an upper beam or lower beam, or both, the lamps shall also conform to TSD 108, except that despite S10.18, horizontal aim adjustment is allowed.

Instead of being equipped with headlamps as required under subsection (1) or (2), as the case may be, passenger cars, three-wheeled vehicles, multi-purpose passenger vehicles, trucks and buses may be equipped with headlamps that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a passenger car, multi-purpose passenger vehicle, truck or bus, conform to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: United Nations Regulation No. 8, Uniform Provisions Concerning the Approval of Motor Vehicle Headlamps Emitting an Asymmetrical Passing Beam or a Driving Beam or Both and Equipped with Halogen Filament Lamps (H1, H2, H3, HB3, HB4, H7, H8, H9, HIR1, HIR2 and/or H11), as amended from time to time,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: United Nations Regulation No. 20, Uniform Provisions Concerning the Approval of Motor Vehicle Headlamps Emitting an Asymmetrical Passing Beam or a Driving Beam or Both and Equipped with Halogen Filament Lamps (H4 Lamps), as amended from time to time,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: United Nations Regulation No. 31, Uniform Provisions Concerning the Approval of Power-Driven Vehicle’s Halogen Sealed-beam Headlamps (HSB) Emitting a European Asymmetrical Passing Beam or a Driving Beam or Both, as amended from time to time,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: United Nations Regulation No. 98, Uniform Provisions Concerning the Approval of Motor Vehicle Headlamps Equipped with Gas-discharge Light Sources, as amended from time to time, or

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: United Nations Regulation No. 112, Uniform Provisions Concerning the Approval of Motor Vehicle Headlamps Emitting an Asymmetrical Passing-beam or a Driving-beam or Both and Equipped with Filament Lamps and/or Light-emitting Diode (LED) Modules, as amended from time to time;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a three-wheeled vehicle, conform to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the regulation referred to in subparagraph (a)(i), (ii) or (v), or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the regulation referred to in subparagraph (a)(iii) or (iv), as if the vehicle were a passenger car;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: are installed on the vehicle in such a manner as to produce only a beam pattern for right-hand traffic, and, if the vehicle is fitted with a mechanism that allows the headlamps to produce a beam pattern for left-hand traffic, that mechanism is inoperative; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: conform to, as applicable, the physical tests referred to in the following provisions of TSD 108:

Subsection.Text: Instead of being equipped with headlamps in accordance with subsection (1) or (2), as the case may be, passenger cars, three-wheeled vehicles, multi-purpose passenger vehicles, trucks and buses may be equipped with headlamps that conform to United Nations Regulation No. 123, Uniform Provisions Concerning the Approval of Adaptive Front-lighting Systems (AFS) for Motor Vehicles, as amended from time to time.
The headlamps referred to in subsection (6) shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be installed

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in accordance with paragraph 6.22 of United Nations Regulation No. 48, Uniform Provisions Concerning the Approval of Vehicles with Regard to the Installation of Lighting and Light-signalling Devices, as amended from time to time, except that, despite paragraph 6.22.6.2, the automatic levelling device is mandatory in all cases, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in such a manner as to produce only a beam pattern for right-hand traffic and, if the vehicle is fitted with a mechanism that allows the headlamps to produce a beam pattern for left-hand traffic, that mechanism shall be inoperative; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: above a mounting height of 850 mm, have a maximum intensity that does not exceed the intensity requirements under TSD 108 for upper beam headlamps where the mounting height is measured to the centre of the highest mounted lamp.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsections (5) and (6), the following requirements of the United Nations Regulations referred to in those subsections do not apply:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any requirements respecting the type-approval process;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any requirements respecting the marking of type-approved headlamps; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any requirements respecting

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the conformity of production of type-approved headlamps,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the penalties for non-conformity of production, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the modification of a headlamp type and extension of approval.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (6) and subparagraph (7)(a)(i), United Nations Regulations Nos. 48 and 123 are considered to be applicable to three-wheeled vehicles, despite any provision to the contrary in those Regulations.
Every motorcycle other than a motor tricycle shall conform to TSD 108, except that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: S6.1.3.5.1 (Vertical headlamp arrangement) does not apply; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: despite S10.18, S10.18.1 applies to motorcycles except that “both vertical and horizontal aim” shall be read as “the vertical aim”.

Subsection.Text: Every motor tricycle shall conform to TSD 108, except that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the following provisions of TSD 108 do not apply:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: S6.1.3.5.1 (Vertical headlamp arrangement), and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: S10.17.1.2.2 (distance between headlamps);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: despite S10.18, S10.18.1 applies to motor tricycles except that “both vertical and horizontal aim” shall be read as “the vertical aim”;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: despite S6.1.1 and S6.1.3.1 and Table I-c, a motor tricycle shall be equipped with tail lamps, stop lamps and reflex reflectors in the number and at the mounting locations specified in Table I-a for passenger cars; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: instead of being equipped with headlamps as specified in S6.1 and Table I-c, a motor tricycle may be equipped with lower beam headlamps and upper beam headlamps as specified in S6.1 and Table I-a for passenger cars.

Subsection.Text: In addition to being equipped with reflex reflectors and lamps as specified in S6.1 and Table I-c of TSD 108, a motor tricycle shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: equipped with parking lamps as specified in S6.1 and Table I-a of TSD 108 for passenger cars;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if an outermost parking lamp is installed more than 400 mm from the nearest of the two outer edges of the motor tricycle that are used to determine the overall width of the motor tricycle, equipped with a white forward-facing reflex reflector that is installed not more than 400 mm from that edge to indicate the width of the motor tricycle; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if an outermost tail lamp or outermost rear reflex reflector is installed more than 400 mm from the nearest of the two outer edges of the motor tricycle that are used to determine the overall width of the motor tricycle, equipped with a red rearward-facing reflex reflector that is installed not more than 400 mm from that edge to indicate the width of the motor tricycle.

Subsection.Text: Instead of being equipped with headlamps as required under subsection (10) or (11), as the case may be, motorcycles may be equipped with headlamps that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: conform to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection (5),

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: United Nations Regulation No. 57, Uniform Provisions Concerning the Approval of Headlamps for Motor Cycles and Vehicles Treated as Such, as amended from time to time,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: United Nations Regulation No. 72, Uniform Provisions Concerning the Approval of Motor Cycle Headlamps Emitting an Asymmetrical Passing Beam and a Driving Beam and Equipped with Halogen Lamps (HS1 Lamps), as amended from time to time, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: United Nations Regulation No. 113, Uniform Provisions Concerning the Approval of Motor Vehicle Headlamps Emitting a Symmetrical Passing Beam or a Driving Beam or Both and Equipped with Filament, Gas-discharge Light Sources or LED Modules, as amended from time to time;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: are installed in accordance with the requirements of paragraphs 5.7, 5.11, 5.13, 6.1 and 6.2 of United Nations Regulation No. 53, Uniform Provisions Concerning the Approval of Category L3 Vehicles with Regard to the Installation of Lighting and Light-Signalling Devices, as amended from time to time; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of headlamps conforming to a Regulation referred to in subparagraph (a)(ii), (iii) or (iv), conform to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the performance requirements of the vibration test, moisture test, dust test and corrosion test described in S14.5 of TSD 108, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of headlamps that do not incorporate a glass lens, the performance requirements of the plastic optical materials tests described in S14.4 of TSD 108.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (13), the following requirements of the United Nations Regulations referred to in that subsection do not apply:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any requirements respecting the type-approval process;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any requirements respecting the marking of type-approved headlamps; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any requirements respecting

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the conformity of production of type-approved headlamps,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the penalties for non-conformity of production, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the modification of a headlamp type and extension of approval.

Subsection.Text: Every restricted-use motorcycle shall be equipped with reflex reflectors as required under subsection (10) for motorcycles other than motor tricycles.

Heading.TitleText: Additional Requirements for the Activation of Certain Lamps

Subsection.Text: In addition to being activated as specified in Table I-a of TSD 108, parking lamps, tail lamps, licence plate lamps and side marker lamps on a passenger car, multi-purpose passenger vehicle, three-wheeled vehicle, truck or bus shall be activated

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: while the front fog lamps on the vehicle are activated in a steady-burning state other than as daytime running lamps; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: while the rear fog lamps on the vehicle are activated in a steady-burning state.

Subsection.Text: Except when it is used to give intermittent luminous warnings at short intervals, the upper beam may be activated only when the master light switch is in the “headlamps on” position or in the “AUTO” (automatic) position and the conditions for automatic activation of the lower beam exist.
Despite S6.1.5 and Table I-a of TSD 108, the tail lamps may be activated without the concurrent activation of the headlamps or parking lamps, if the daytime running lamps are activated.

Beginning on September 1, 2021, if the fuel level indicator, oil pressure indicator, engine coolant temperature indicator, battery charging indicator, transmission control position indicator or speedometer indicator or their identifications are illuminated when the daytime running lights of a vehicle are in use,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the lower beam headlamps shall

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: automatically activate in a steady-burning state in less than two seconds when the ambient light outside the vehicle is less than 1,000 lux while the transmission control is in the forward or reverse position and the vehicle is in motion, unless the lower beam headlamps were deactivated manually after their automatic activation following the most recent disarming of the immobilization system in accordance with section 114, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: automatically deactivate under the conditions set out by the manufacturer; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the tail lamps shall be alight.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of paragraph (19)(a), the ambient light outside a vehicle shall be measured on a horizontal surface, with a cosine corrected sensor at the same height as the mounting position of the ambient light sensor on the vehicle.

Heading.TitleText: Fog Lamps and Forward Auxiliary Road Illumination Lamps — Aiming Adjustment Mechanism

Subsection.Text: Every passenger car, multi-purpose passenger vehicle, three-wheeled vehicle, motor tricycle, truck and bus equipped with a front fog lamp or forward auxiliary road illumination lamp shall be equipped with a mechanism for that lamp that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: allows aim adjustment of the vertical aim by one person to maintain the beam pattern of the lamp within the full range of vertical pitch of the vehicle, with the use of ordinarily available tools; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: allows the adjustment referred to in paragraph (a) after being subjected to the corrosion test procedure set out in S14.6.3.1 of TSD 108.

Subsection.Text: There shall be provided, in the owner’s manual, with every passenger car, multi-purpose passenger vehicle, truck and bus, the information required by TSD 108 in relation to the safe operation of the lighting systems and reflective devices of the vehicle.

There shall be provided, in the owner’s manual, with every three-wheeled vehicle, information relating to the safe operation of the lighting systems and reflective devices of the vehicle that is the same as the information required by TSD 108 in relation to passenger cars.

Except for the words “sealed beam” referred to in S6.5.3.3.1 of TSD 108 and the word “motorcycle” referred to in S10.17.2 of TSD 108, any information required under this section to be marked on a passenger car, multi-purpose passenger vehicle, three-wheeled vehicle, motorcycle, restricted-use motorcycle, trailer, truck or bus shall be in English and French.
Subsections (26) to (30) apply to passenger cars, multi-purpose passenger vehicles, trucks, buses and three-wheeled vehicles.
Every vehicle shall be equipped with daytime running lamps

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in accordance with S6.1.3.1 of TSD 108, except that the reference to “applicable photometric requirements” in that provision is a reference to the applicable photometric requirements set out in SAE Standard J2087, Daytime Running Light (August 2017) (SAE Standard J2087);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in accordance with S6.2 of TSD 108, except that the references in that provision to “lighting equipment required by this TSD” and to “required lamp” include a reference to “daytime running lamp”; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: that conform to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: sections 5, 6 and 7.3.1 of SAE Standard J2087, except that despite section 6.1.2, if a daytime running lamp is optically combined with a white front position lamp that has a projected luminous lens area of 200 cm2 or less, it may conform to the light intensity distribution values shown in figure 1 when tested in accordance with section 5.1, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: until September 1, 2020, SAE Standard J583, Front Fog Lamps (September 2016) (SAE Standard J583).

Subsection.Text: Despite section 6.4 of SAE Standard J2087, the light from a daytime running lamp shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the lamp is optically combined with a parking lamp, white or yellow;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if produced by a turn signal lamp, yellow; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in all other cases, white.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (29) and (30), the daytime running lamps on a vehicle shall be activated not later than when the vehicle is set in motion under its own power and shall remain activated until the motors or engines used for the vehicle’s propulsion are switched off and as a result the vehicle enters a mode of operation other than “accessory” or “on”.
The daytime running lamps on a vehicle shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be deactivated while the lower beam headlamps are activated to provide road illumination;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: beginning on September 1, 2020, be deactivated while the front fog lamps provide road illumination after being activated by the driver; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if they also serve as front turn signal lamps,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: be deactivated on the side of the vehicle where a turn signal is activated, while that turn signal is activated, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: be deactivated on both sides of the vehicle while the hazard warning signal is activated.

Subsection.Text: The daytime running lamps on a vehicle may be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: deactivated while the parking brake is applied or the transmission control is in the park or neutral position and the vehicle is not in motion;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: deactivated while the headlamps are being flashed for signalling purposes;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: switched off manually, in which case they shall reactivate automatically, at the discretion of the manufacturer, either not later than when the vehicle travels more than 100 m or when the speed of the vehicle exceeds 10 km/h; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: wired to flash for signalling purposes.

Subsection.Text: The following lamps on a motorcycle shall be activated not later than when the motorcycle is set in motion under its own power and shall remain activated until the motorcycle’s main electrical system is turned off or until the motorcycle is put in the “accessory” mode of operation:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: every tail lamp;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: every licence plate lamp; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: every headlamp or, as an alternative, one or two lamps that conform to the requirements for dedicated daytime running lamps set out in SAE Standard J2087.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this section, “equipment” in TSD 108 shall be read as “component”.
For the purposes of this section,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: “dipped beam” and “passing beam” in United Nations Regulations Nos. 8, 20, 31, 48, 53, 57, 72, 98, 112, 113 and 123 shall be read as “lower beam” or as “lower beam headlamp”, as the context requires; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: “driving beam” and “main beam” in United Nations Regulations Nos. 8, 20, 31, 48, 53, 57, 72, 98, 112, 113 and 123 shall be read as “upper beam” or as “upper beam headlamp”, as the context requires.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of section 7.3.1 of SAE Standard J2087 and section 5.2.5.1 of SAE Standard J583, “should” shall be interpreted as expressing an obligation.

Despite subsections (1) to (34), a vehicle may, until August 31, 2019, conform to the requirements of this section that are applicable to a lighting system or reflective device, as they read immediately before the day on which this subsection comes into force.

Heading.TitleText: Tire Selection and Rims for Motor Vehicles With a GVWR of 4 536 KG or Less (Standard 110)

Subsection.Text: Every motor vehicle with a GVWR of 4 536 kg or less — except motorcycles other than motor tricycles equipped with passenger car tires, restricted-use motorcycles, three-wheeled vehicles equipped with tires other than passenger car tires, vehicles imported temporarily for special purposes and low-speed vehicles — and every tire rim manufactured for use on those vehicles shall conform to the requirements of Technical Standards Document No. 110, Tire Selection and Rims for Motor Vehicles With a GVWR of 4,536 kg or Less (TSD 110), as amended from time to time.
Except as provided in subsections (3) and (4), the information specified in S4.3 and S4.3.5 of TSD 110 shall appear, at the option of the manufacturer, either

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in both official languages on one vehicle placard, as shown in Figure 3, or, if the manufacturer chooses to use a tire inflation pressure label, on one placard and one label, as shown in Figures 3 and 6; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in each official language on two vehicle placards, as shown in Figures 1 and 2, or, if the manufacturer chooses to use a tire inflation pressure label, on two placards and two labels, as shown in Figures 1, 2, 4 and 5, affixed at the same location on the vehicle but apart.

Subsection.Text: The information specified in S4.3(f) of TSD 110 that appears on a vehicle placard and, at the manufacturer’s option, on a tire inflation pressure label, in accordance with paragraph (2)(a), shall appear either

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the form of the symbol number N.03 for Operator’s manual, operation instructions, that is included in International Standard ISO 2575, entitled Road vehicles — Symbols for controls, indicators and tell-tales, 7th edition, May 1, 2004; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in both official languages on one placard, as shown in Figure 3, or on one placard and one label, as shown in Figures 3 and 6.

Subsection.Text: The information specified in S4.3(f) of TSD 110 that appears on a vehicle placard and, at the manufacturer’s option, on a tire inflation pressure label, in accordance with paragraph 2(b), shall appear either

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the form of the symbol number N.03 specified in paragraph (3)(a); or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in each official language on two placards, as shown in Figures 1 and 2, or on two placards and two labels, as shown in Figures 1, 2, 4 and 5, affixed at the same location on the vehicle but apart.

Subsection.Text: The words “Voir le manuel de l’usager pour plus de renseignements”, in the French version of the information specified in S4.3(f) of TSD 110, may, at the option of the manufacturer, be replaced by the words “Voir le guide du propriétaire pour plus de renseignements”, “Voir le manuel du propriétaire pour plus de renseignements” or “Voir le guide de l’automobiliste pour plus de renseignements”.
The information specified in S4.3.3 of TSD 110 shall be in both official languages.
The following definitions apply for the purposes of TSD 110.

Definition.Text: load rating means the maximum load a tire is rated to carry at a given inflation pressure. (charge nominale)
maximum load rating means the load rating at the maximum permissible inflation pressure for that tire. (limite de charge nominale)
rim base means that portion of a rim remaining after the removal of all split or continuous rim flanges, side rings, and locking rings that can be detached from the rim. (base de jante)

Subsection.Text: In the case of vehicles equipped with light-truck tires, the load range identification symbol shall appear either on the compliance label required by section 6 of these Regulations or on the vehicle placard or tire inflation pressure label, after the tire size designation.

Subsection.Text: Any mirror referred to in this section that is installed on a vehicle shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have a stable support;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be adjustable in the horizontal and vertical directions;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be a unit magnification mirror, except in the cases referred to in subsection (6), paragraph (13)(b) and subsection (16);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: be free of sharp points or edges that could cause an injury to an occupant of the vehicle or to a pedestrian;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: except in the case of a System B mirror installed on a school bus that has a forward control configuration, be installed so that the driver’s field of view through the mirror is not obscured by the portion of the windshield that is not wiped by the windshield wipers or by any opaque portion of the vehicle structure; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an outside rearview mirror, have no greater protrusion beyond the perimeter of the vehicle than is necessary to meet the field-of-view requirements for the mirror prescribed in this section.

Subsection.Text: A rearview mirror referred to in subsection (7) or (11) or paragraph (26)(a) shall be capable of adjustment from within the occupant compartment of the vehicle.
The average reflectance of a mirror referred to in this section shall be determined in accordance with SAE Standard J964, Test Procedure for Determining Reflectivity of Rear View Mirrors (June 1992).
A mirror referred to in this section that is a single reflectance mirror shall have a reflectance level of at least 35 per cent.

A mirror referred to in this section that is a multiple reflectance mirror shall have a daytime reflectance level of at least 35 per cent and a night-time reflectance level of at least 4 per cent. In the event of electrical failure, the mirror shall be adjustable, either manually or automatically, to a reflectance level of at least 35 per cent.
An outside rearview mirror referred to in paragraph (7)(b) or subsection (26) or (27) that is installed on the side of the vehicle opposite the driver’s side may be convex if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: its reflective surface area is equal to or greater than the reflective surface area that a unit magnification mirror must have in accordance with that paragraph or subsection;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: its average radius of curvature is not less than 890 mm (35 inches) and not greater than 1 800 mm (71.5 inches); and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the radius of curvature at any point does not deviate by more than 12.5 per cent from the average of any five radius-of-curvature measurements made on its reflective surface at least 6 mm (0.25 inch) from the edge of the image display.

Subsection.Text: An inside rearview mirror shall be installed on every passenger car and three-wheeled vehicle and shall, under the conditions prescribed in subsection (8),

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: provide the driver with a field of view to the rear that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is not less than 20° measured horizontally rearward from the projected eye point, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: extends to the horizon and includes a point on the road surface not more than 60 m (200 feet) directly behind the vehicle; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the inside rearview mirror does not provide the field of view to the rear described in paragraph (a), be accompanied, on the side opposite the driver’s side, by an outside rearview mirror that has not less than 90 per cent of the reflective surface area of an outside rearview mirror installed pursuant to subsection (11).

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (7), the vehicle shall be on a level road surface and loaded with the lighter of the following loads, calculated on the basis of the driver and each occupant weighing 68 kg (150 pounds):

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a driver and four other occupants, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an occupant in each designated seating position.

Subsection.Text: A field of view to the rear described in paragraph (7)(a) may be partially obscured by seated occupants or head restraints.

An inside rearview mirror referred to in subsection (7), if situated in the head impact area, shall, when the reflective surface of the mirror is subjected to a force of 400 N (90 pounds) in any direction that is not more than 45° from the forward longitudinal direction, deflect, collapse or break away without leaving sharp edges.

An outside rearview mirror shall be installed on the driver’s side of every passenger car and three-wheeled vehicle in such a manner as to provide the driver with a field of view to the rear on a level road surface that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: may be partially obscured by the rear body or fender contours;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: extends to the horizon; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: includes a line measuring 2.5 m (8 feet) perpendicular to and outboard from the vertical longitudinal plane tangent to the driver’s side of the vehicle at its widest part, at a point 10.6 m (35 feet) behind the eyes of the driver seated with the driver’s seat in the rearmost position.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsections (7), (9) and (11), the field of view to the rear of the driver shall be evaluated by using

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the location of the driver’s eye reference points for the 95th percentile tangential cut-off specified in SAE Recommended Practice J941a, Passenger Car Driver’s Eye Range (August 1967); or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the driver’s eye reference points at a nominal location appropriate for any 95th percentile adult male driver.

Subsection.Text: Every motorcycle shall have, mounted on each side so that the horizontal centre of each reflective surface of the mirror is at least 280 mm (11 inches) outward from the longitudinal centreline of the motorcycle,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a rearview mirror with not less than 80 cm2 (12.5 square inches) of reflective surface area; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a convex rearview mirror with not less than 64.5 cm2 (10 square inches) of reflective surface area and an average radius of curvature that is not less than 510 mm (20 inches) and not greater than 1 800 mm (71.5 inches).

Subsection.Text: As an alternative to the rearview mirrors required by subsection (13), a motorcycle may be equipped with rearview mirrors that conform to paragraph 16 of United Nations Regulation No. 81, Uniform Provisions Concerning the Approval of Rear-view Mirrors of Two-wheeled Power-driven Vehicles with or without Side Car, with Regard to the Installation of Rear-view Mirrors on Handlebars (United Nations Regulation No. 81), as amended by any amendment prior to the 01 series of amendments.
Despite paragraph 16.2.1 of United Nations Regulation No. 81, all two-wheeled vehicles with a maximum speed of 50 km/h or less shall be equipped with two rearview mirrors.

For the purposes of subsections (13.1) and (13.2), a reference in United Nations Regulation No. 81 to “two-wheeled vehicle” or “three-wheeled vehicle” is to be read as a reference to “motorcycle”, and a reference to “maximum designed speed” is to be read as a reference to “maximum speed”.

For the purposes of subsections (16) to (25), a driver’s eye position shall be represented by the left and right eye points as defined in SAE Recommended Practice J1050, Describing and Measuring the Driver’s Field of View (August 1994), and shall be at any place within the area defined by a 95th percentile eyellipse in accordance with SAE Recommended Practice J941, Motor Vehicle Drivers’ Eye Locations (June 1997), with the following adaptations:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a 50/50 male-to-female ratio must be used for the male/female mix; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: heel point referred to in that Recommended Practice and in other documents referenced in that Recommended Practice means the accelerator heel point (AHP) as defined in section 3.16.1 of SAE Recommended Practice J1100, Motor Vehicle Dimensions (February 2001), and the position of the heel point is that determined by the manufacturer.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsections (16) to (25),

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: cylinders A, D and E shall be 0.305 m (1 foot) high and 0.305 m (1 foot) in diameter;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: cylinders B and C shall be 0.915 m (3 feet) high and 0.305 m (1 foot) in diameter; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: cylinders A, B, C, D and E shall be of a colour that provides a high contrast with the road surface on which the bus is parked.

Subsection.Text: Every school bus shall have the following two outside mirror systems:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: System A, which consists, on each side of the school bus, of one unit magnification mirror that conforms to subsection (18) and one convex mirror that conforms to subsection (19); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: System B, which consists, on each side of the school bus, of one convex mirror that conforms to subsections (20) to (24).

Subsection.Text: A System A mirror and System B mirror shall conform to the provisions referred to in subsection (16) at any driver’s eye position, when they are adjusted in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions.

Each System A unit magnification mirror shall have a reflective surface area of not less than 325 cm2 (50 square inches) that provides, at the driver’s eye position, a field of view that includes a continuous view rearward, of the side of the school bus and the road surface, which view shall begin no farther than 60 m (200 feet) rearward of the mirror’s surface and extend to the horizon when measured on a level road, as illustrated in Figure 1.
Each System A convex mirror shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: provide, at the driver’s eye position, a field of view that includes continuous and complete views as illustrated in Figure 1,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: rearward,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: of the ground, which view overlaps the field of view provided by the unit magnification mirror described in subsection (18),

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: of the side of the bus,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: in the mirror installed on the side opposite the driver’s side, of cylinders B and D, placed in accordance with subsection (25), and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: in the mirror installed on the driver’s side, of cylinders C and E, placed in accordance with subsection (25);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have an average radius of curvature of not less than 482 mm (19 inches); and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: have a radius of curvature that does not deviate at any point by more than 12.5 per cent from the average of any five radius-of-curvature measurements taken at least 6 mm (0.25 inch) from the edge of the reflective surface.

Subsection.Text: Each System B mirror shall be installed so that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the distance from the driver’s eye position to the centre of the mirror is at least 95.25 cm (37.5 inches); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the slope of the mirror surface has no discontinuities.

Subsection.Text: Each System B mirror shall provide a field of view that includes continuous and complete views at the driver’s eye position, as illustrated in Figure 1, of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the ground from the front bumper forward to a point where direct observation of the ground is possible;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the ground and the side of the bus rearward of the front bumper, extending to and overlapping the field of view provided by the System A convex mirror;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a mirror installed on the side opposite the driver’s side, of cylinders A and B, placed in accordance with subsection (25), and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a mirror installed on the driver’s side, of cylinders A and C, placed in accordance with subsection (25).

Subsection.Text: The images of cylinders A, B and C, placed in accordance with subsection (25), that are reflected in each System B mirror shall meet the following requirements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the shortest angular width of the image shall be no less than 3 minutes of arc, measured using the following equation:

FormulaDefinition.Text: is the width of the image of the cylinder on the reflective surface,
is the distance between the centre point of the driver’s eye position and the centre of the reflective surface, and
is the tangent of 3 minutes of arc; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the shortest angular length of the image shall be no less than 9 minutes of arc, measured using the following equation:

FormulaDefinition.Text: is the length of the image of the cylinder on the reflective surface,
is the distance between the centre point of the driver’s eye position and the centre of the reflective surface, and
is the tangent of 9 minutes of arc.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (22), a comparison chart, such as the one shown in Figure 2, may be used to measure the angular width and angular length of an image of a cylinder, where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the comparison chart is placed in a vertical plane that contains the image to be evaluated;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the plane of the comparison chart is perpendicular to the line of sight;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the image of the cylinder and the comparison chart are visible through the still or video camera’s viewfinder;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a photograph is taken at the driver’s eye position; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the image of the cylinder is larger than the references shown on the comparison chart.

Subsection.Text: Images reflected in each System B mirror shall be located no less than 3 minutes of arc from the edge of the reflective surface, when measured at the driver’s eye position.
A System A mirror and a System B mirror shall be tested as follows:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: cylinders A, B, C, D and E shall be placed at the following locations, as illustrated in Figure 1, with measurements taken from the centre of the cylinder, as viewed from above:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: cylinder A shall be placed in front of the bus so that its centre passes through the bus’s longitudinal centreline and its top is directly visible through the portion of the windshield wiped by the windshield wipers at the driver’s eye position,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: cylinder B shall be placed on the side opposite the driver’s side at a point where the cylinder is entirely visible through the convex mirrors of both System A and System B on that side so that its centre falls in a vertical plane that is 2 m (6.6 feet) to the right of, and perpendicular to, a vertical plane tangent to the bus’s most outboard surface,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: cylinder C shall be placed on the driver’s side at a point where the cylinder is entirely visible through the convex mirrors of both System A and System B on that side so that its centre falls in a vertical plane that is 2 m (6.6 feet) to the left of, and perpendicular to, a vertical plane tangent to the bus’s most outboard surface,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: cylinder D shall be placed on the side opposite the driver’s side so that its centre falls in the vertical plane that passes through the centreline of the bus’s rear-wheel axle and that is 2 m (6.6 feet) to the right of the bus’s most outboard surface, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: cylinder E shall be placed on the driver’s side so that its centre falls in the vertical plane that passes through the centreline of the bus’s rear-wheel axle and that is 2 m (6.6 feet) to the left of the bus’s most outboard surface;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: every mirror shall be adjusted in accordance with the manufacturer’s recommendations to the driver’s eye position and is not to be moved or readjusted during testing for that eye position but may be readjusted for subsequent tests for different eye positions;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a still or video camera shall be positioned so that its image plane is located at the driver’s eye point in such a manner that the reflective surface is visible to the camera through the windows of the bus;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: for a specific driver’s eye position, the requirements of subsections (16) to (25) shall be satisfied with the still or video camera positioned at either the left or right eye point;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the still or video camera shall be supported so as to allow pivoting

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in the vertical and horizontal planes of its image plane to no greater than the maximum allowable limits of eye rotation specified in SAE Recommended Practice J1050, Describing and Measuring the Driver’s Field of View (August 1994), and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the horizontal plane of its image plane to no greater than the maximum allowable limit of neck rotation specified in SAE Recommended Practice J1050, at a point corresponding to the neck pivot point as specified in that Recommended Practice, only after the maximum limits of eye rotation have been reached;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: all of the still or video camera observations shall be done with the service door of the bus closed and the stop signal arm fully retracted; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: for the purposes of subsection (21), the front bumper shall be the forwardmost structural contour of the bumper excluding the fasteners, protruding discrete bumper stops, and any attached accessories such as crossing control arms, which shall be removed prior to testing.

Subsection.Text: Every multi-purpose passenger vehicle, truck and bus, with a GVWR of 4 536 kg (10,000 pounds) or less, other than a school bus, shall have

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the following rearview mirrors, namely,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: an inside rearview mirror that meets the requirements of subsections (7), (9) and (10),

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: on the driver’s side, an outside rearview mirror that meets the field-of-view requirements of subsection (11), and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: on the side opposite the driver’s side, an outside rearview mirror that has not less than 90 per cent of the reflective surface area of the outside rearview mirror installed on the driver’s side; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on each side of the vehicle, an outside rearview mirror of which not less than 125 cm2 (19.5 square inches) of reflective surface area is located so as to provide the driver with a view to the rear along both sides of the vehicle.

Subsection.Text: Every multi-purpose passenger vehicle, truck and bus with a GVWR of more than 4 536 kg (10,000 pounds), other than a school bus, shall have on each side of the vehicle an outside rearview mirror of which not less than 325 cm2 (50 square inches) of reflective surface area is located so as to provide the driver with a view to the rear along both sides of the vehicle.

A company may ship a vehicle bearing a compliance label or information label, as the case may be, on which no outside mirrors have been installed, if the applicable outside mirrors and all of the hardware that is necessary for their mounting accompany the vehicle and all of the holes that are necessary for mounting those mirrors have been made in the sheet metal of the vehicle.

Subject to subsection (32), every passenger car and three-wheeled vehicle with a GVWR of 4 536 kg or less that is manufactured on or after the day specified in S5.5(b) of section 571.111, chapter V, Title 49 of the Code of Federal Regulations of the United States, as amended from time to time, shall be equipped with a rear visibility system that conforms to the requirements for rear visibility set out in S5.5, other than S5.5(a), of that section, as amended from time to time, and that is tested in accordance with the rear visibility test procedure set out in S14 of that section, as amended from time to time.

Subject to subsection (33), every multi-purpose passenger vehicle, low-speed vehicle, truck and bus with a GVWR of 4 536 kg or less that is manufactured on or after the day specified in S6.2(b) of section 571.111, chapter V, Title 49 of the Code of Federal Regulations of the United States, as amended from time to time, shall be equipped with a rear visibility system that conforms to the requirements for rear visibility set out in S6.2, other than S6.2(a), of that section, as amended from time to time, and that is tested in accordance with the rear visibility test procedure set out in S14 of that section, as amended from time to time.
For the purposes of subsections (29) and (30),

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: rear visibility system has the same meaning as in S4 of section 571.111, chapter V, Title 49 of the Code of Federal Regulations of the United States, as amended from time to time;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a reference to the term “backing event”, “environmental test fixture”, “external component”, “key”, “rearview image” or “rear visibility system” in S4, S5.5, S6.2 or S14 of section 571.111, chapter V, Title 49 of the Code of Federal Regulations of the United States, as amended from time to time, is to be read as a reference to that term as defined in S4; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a reference to “starting system” in S4, including its definition, or S14 of section 571.111, chapter V, Title 49 of the Code of Federal Regulations of the United States, as amended from time to time, is to be read as a reference to “ignition switch”.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (29) does not apply to a vehicle to which an information label has been applied under subsection 6.4(1), to which a compliance label has been applied under paragraph 6.6(1)(b) or to which an additional label has been applied under paragraph 9(1)(c) if the vehicle is manufactured before the first anniversary of the day specified in S5.5(b) of section 571.111, chapter V, Title 49 of the Code of Federal Regulations of the United States, as amended from time to time.

Subsection (30) does not apply to a vehicle to which an information label has been applied under subsection 6.4(1), to which a compliance label has been applied under paragraph 6.6(1)(b) or to which an additional label has been applied under paragraph 9(1)(c) if the vehicle is manufactured before the first anniversary of the day specified in S6.2(b) of section 571.111, chapter V, Title 49 of the Code of Federal Regulations of the United States, as amended from time to time.

Subsection.Text: In this section, hood means any exterior movable body panel forward of the windshield that is used to cover an engine, luggage, storage or battery compartment.
Each hood with which a vehicle is equipped shall be provided with a hood latch system.

A front-opening hood that, in any position, partially or completely obstructs a driver’s forward view through the windshield of the vehicle shall be provided with a second latching position on the hood latch system or with a second hood latch system.

With the exception of a walk-in van, every passenger car, every three-wheeled vehicle, and every multi-purpose passenger vehicle and truck with a GVWR of 4 536 kg or less shall conform to the requirements of Technical Standards Document No. 114, Theft Protection and Rollaway Prevention (TSD 114), as amended from time to time.
The term self-mobility in TSD 114 means movement of a vehicle under its own power.

With the exception of a walk-in van and an emergency vehicle, every passenger car, every three-wheeled vehicle, and every multi-purpose passenger vehicle and truck with a GVWR of 4 536 kg or less shall be equipped with an immobilization system that conforms to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: one of the following sets of requirements as modified by subsection (22), (23) or (24):

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the requirements of section 3, subsection 4.3, sections 6 to 10 and subsections 12.1, 12.2 and 12.16 of National Standard of Canada CAN/ULC-S338-98, entitled Automobile Theft Deterrent Equipment and Systems: Electronic Immobilization (May 1998), published by the Underwriters’ Laboratories of Canada,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the general and particular specifications that are set out in Part III of United Nations Regulation No. 97, entitled Uniform Provisions Concerning the Approval of Vehicle Alarm Systems (VAS) and of Motor Vehicles with Regard to Their Alarm Systems (AS), in the version in effect on August 8, 2007, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the general and particular specifications that are set out in Part IV of United Nations Regulation No. 116, entitled Uniform Provisions Concerning the Protection of Motor Vehicles Against Unauthorized Use, in the version in effect on February 10, 2009; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the requirements set out in subsections (8) to (21).

Subsection.Text: A vehicle equipped with an immobilization system shall be accompanied by the following written information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: instructions for operating and maintaining the system; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a warning not to leave a disarming device or a combination that disarms the system in the vehicle.

Subsection.Text: The information shall be provided in English, French or both official languages, as requested by the first retail purchaser of the vehicle.
In this section, disarming device means a physical device that contains or transmits the code that disarms the immobilization system of a vehicle.

Subject to subsection (9), an immobilization system shall arm automatically within a period of not more than 1 minute after the disarming device is removed from the vehicle, if the vehicle remains in a mode of operation other than “accessory” or “on” throughout that period.

If the disarming device is a keypad or biometric identifier, the immobilization system shall arm automatically within a period of not more than 1 minute after the motors used for the vehicle’s propulsion are turned off, if the vehicle remains in a mode of operation other than “accessory” or “on” throughout that period.
The immobilization system shall arm automatically not later than 2 minutes after the immobilization system is disarmed, unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: action is taken for starting one or more motors used for the vehicle’s propulsion;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: disarming requires an action to be taken on

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the engine start control or electric motor start control,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the engine stop control or electric motor stop control, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the ignition switch; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: disarming occurs automatically by the presence of a disarming device and the device is inside the vehicle.

Subsection.Text: If armed, the immobilization system

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall prevent the vehicle from moving more than 3 m under its own power by inhibiting the operation of at least one electronic control unit; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: shall not have any impact on the vehicle’s brake system except that it may prevent regenerative braking and the release of the parking brake.

Subsection.Text: During the disarming process, a code shall be sent to the inhibited electronic control unit in order to allow the vehicle to move under its own power.
It shall not be possible to disarm the immobilization system by interrupting its normal operating voltage.

When the normal starting procedure requires that the disarming device mechanically latch into a receptacle and the device is physically separate from the ignition switch key, one or more motors used for the vehicle’s propulsion shall start only after the device is removed from that receptacle.
The immobilization system shall conform to the following requirements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it shall have a minimum capacity of 50,000 code variants;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it shall not be disarmed by a code that can disarm all other immobilization systems of the same make and model; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsection (16), it shall not have the capacity to process more than 5,000 codes within 24 hours;

Subsection.Text: If an immobilization system uses rolling or encrypted codes, it may conform to the following requirements, instead of the requirement set out in paragraph (15)(c):

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the probability of obtaining the correct code within 24 hours shall not exceed 4 per cent; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it shall not be possible to disarm the system by re-transmitting in any sequence the previous 5 codes generated by the system.

Subsection.Text: The immobilization system shall be designed so that, when tested as installed in the vehicle,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: neither the replacement of an original immobilization system component with a manufacturer’s replacement component nor the addition of a manufacturer’s component can be completed without the use of software; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it is not possible for the vehicle to move under its own power for at least 5 minutes after the beginning of the replacement or addition of a component referred to in paragraph (a).

Subsection.Text: The immobilization system’s conformity to subsection (17) shall be demonstrated by testing that is carried out without damaging the vehicle.
Paragraph (17)(b) does not apply to the addition of a disarming device that requires the use of another disarming device that is validated by the immobilization system.

The immobilization system shall be designed so that it can neither be bypassed nor rendered ineffective in a manner that would allow a vehicle to move under its own power, or be disarmed, using one or more of the tools and equipment listed in subsection (21),

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: within a period of less than 5 minutes, when tested as installed in the vehicle; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: within a period of less than 2.5 minutes, when bench-tested outside the vehicle.

Subsection.Text: During a test referred to in subsection (20), only the following tools or equipment may be used:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: scissors, wire strippers, wire cutters and electrical wires;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a hammer, a slide hammer, a chisel, a punch, a wrench, a screwdriver and pliers;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: steel rods and spikes;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a hacksaw;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a battery operated drill;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a battery operated angle grinder; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a battery operated jigsaw.

Subsection.Text: The requirements set out in National Standard of Canada CAN/ULC-S338-98 are modified as follows:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the requirements respecting non-OEM systems as defined in section 2 of that document and respecting local noise regulations do not apply;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a reference to a “manufacturer of the electronic immobilization system” is to be read as a reference to a “manufacturer”; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: subsection 8.1 is to be read as follows: “Transponders and remote controls shall be in sealed enclosures that conform to the requirements of Subsections 12.1, General, and 12.2, Normal Operation.”

Subsection.Text: The requirements set out in Part III of United Nations Regulation No. 97 are modified as follows:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the aftermarket, type approval and radio transmission requirements do not apply;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all references to paragraph 33 do not apply;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: for the purposes of paragraph 31.7, the word rapidly means less than 5 minutes and the words time consuming mean at least 5 minutes; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: despite any statement to the contrary in paragraphs 31.10 and 31.11, the immobilization system shall not have any impact on the vehicle’s brake system.

Subsection.Text: The requirements set out in Part IV of United Nations Regulation No. 116 are modified as follows:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the aftermarket, type approval and radio transmission requirements do not apply;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for the purposes of paragraph 8.2.7, the word rapidly means less than 5 minutes and the expression time consuming means at least 5 minutes;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: despite any statement to the contrary in paragraphs 8.2.10 and 8.2.11, the immobilization system shall not have any impact on the vehicle’s brake system; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: all references to paragraph 8.4 do not apply.

Subsection.Text: Every vehicle shall have a vehicle identification number and that vehicle identification number shall not be the same as the vehicle identification number of a vehicle having a model year of 1980 or later manufactured within the preceding 60 years.
A vehicle that is manufactured from an incomplete vehicle shall bear the vehicle identification number assigned by the incomplete vehicle manufacturer.

Where a vehicle identification number is stated on a label bearing a statement of compliance affixed to a vehicle and the vehicle is altered, the vehicle identification number shall apply to the altered vehicle.
Subject to subsection (2.1), the vehicle identification number of each vehicle shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be composed of capital, sanserif characters;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be sunk into, embossed on or imprinted, clearly and indelibly, and in such a manner that the vehicle identification number cannot be removed without damaging or defacing the plate, label or vehicle, on

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: an integral or structural part of the vehicle other than the dash-board pad or dash-board cover,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the dash-board or dash-board cover if it is not designed to be replaced following an air bag deployment, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a separate plate or label that is permanently affixed in a location referred to in subparagraph (i) or (ii); and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a low-speed vehicle, multi-purpose passenger vehicle, passenger car, three-wheeled vehicle or truck having a GVWR of 4 536 kg or less, be

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: composed of characters having a minimum height of 4 mm,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: located inside the occupant compartment, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: without any part of such vehicle being removed, readable through the vehicle glazing under daylight conditions by an observer having 20/20 vision Snellen whose eyepoint is located outside the vehicle adjacent to the left windshield pillar.

Subsection.Text: The vehicle identification number of a snowmobile shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be composed of capital, sans serif characters;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be sunk into, embossed on, imprinted on or permanently affixed on the right exterior vertical surface of the track tunnel;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be difficult to remove, replace or alter without detection;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: be composed of characters having a minimum height of 4 mm;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: be legible and indelible;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: be legible without any part of the vehicle having to be removed; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: be protected from corrosion.

Subsection.Text: At the option of the manufacturer, the vehicle identification number may also be displayed in a bar code format that shall meet the requirements of section 5.6 of guideline AIAG B-10, Trading Partner Labels Implementation Guideline (February, 2000), except for the specifications respecting code density and dimensions, which shall meet the requirements of section 4.1 of standard AIAG B-2, Vehicle Identification Number Label Standard (June, 1988).
Every bar coded vehicle identification number shall be displayed on

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the vehicle’s compliance or information label; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a separate label that is applied beside the compliance or information label in accordance with paragraphs 7(a) and (b) of these Regulations.

Subsection.Text: If the vehicle identification number is displayed on a label in a bar code format, it need not, until September 1, 2012, also be applied to the vehicle in accordance with paragraph 115(2)(b), but may, at the option of the manufacturer, be sunk into, embossed on or imprinted, clearly and indelibly, on

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any part of the vehicle that is not designed to be removed except for repair, other than glazing; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a separate plate or label that is permanently affixed to a part referred to in paragraph (a).

Subsection.Text: The vehicle identification number of any vehicle shall be alphanumeric and shall be composed of 17 characters as follows:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the first three characters, the third of which shall not be “9”, shall uniquely identify the manufacturer and the class of vehicle, if the manufacturer manufactures 1,000 or more vehicles of a prescribed class annually;

Paragraph.Label: (a.1)
Paragraph.Text: the first three characters, the third of which shall be “9”, and the twelfth to fourteenth characters shall uniquely identify the manufacturer and the class of vehicle, if the manufacturer manufactures less than 1,000 vehicles of a prescribed class annually;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the fourth to eighth characters, inclusive, shall uniquely identify the decipherable information for the vehicle as set out in Column II of Table I, except that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the seventh character shall be alphabetic for a multi-purpose passenger vehicle, passenger car, three-wheeled vehicle or truck having a GVWR of 4 536 kg or less,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: subject to subparagraph (i), the characters and their positioning may be determined by the manufacturer, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of an incomplete vehicle to be completed as a trailer, the decipherable information required for an incomplete vehicle in column II of Table I shall be that for a trailer;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the ninth character shall be the check digit determined in accordance with subsections (7) and (8) after all other characters have been determined by the manufacturer;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the tenth character shall be the code that corresponds to the vehicle model year as set out in Table II;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the eleventh character shall identify the plant of manufacture of the vehicle;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the twelfth to seventeenth characters shall be sequentially assigned by the manufacturer during the manufacturing process, if the manufacturer manufactures 1,000 or more vehicles of a prescribed class annually;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the fifteenth to seventeenth characters shall be sequentially assigned by the manufacturer during the manufacturing process, if the manufacturer manufactures less than 1,000 vehicles of a prescribed class annually; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the fourteenth to seventeenth characters shall be numeric for all vehicles and the thirteenth character shall be numeric if the vehicle is a multi-purpose passenger vehicle, passenger car, three-wheeled vehicle or truck having a GVWR of 4 536 kg or less.

Subsection.Text: Each character used in a vehicle identification number shall be one of the Arabic numerals or Roman letters specified in Table III.
The check digit referred to in paragraph (3)(c) shall be determined by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: assigning to each numeral of the vehicle identification number the actual mathematical value of that numeral;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: assigning to each letter the mathematical value for that letter specified in Table IV;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: multiplying the assigned value for each character of the vehicle identification number by the weight factor set out opposite that character in Table V; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: adding together the numbers obtained under paragraph (c) and dividing the total by 11.

Subsection.Text: The fractional portion of the quotient obtained by paragraph (7)(d), multiplied by 11, shall be the check digit, except that if that product is 10, the check digit shall be X.

The Minister may require manufacturers of vehicles in respect of which this section applies to submit to the Minister those characters that uniquely identify a vehicle including, where applicable, the twelfth to fourteenth characters, inclusive, that constitute part of the identifier, for each make and class of vehicle manufactured and, in all cases, the information necessary to decipher the characters in vehicle identification numbers.

If a character in a vehicle identification number identifies engine net power, the engine net power represented by that character shall not differ by more than 10 per cent from the actual engine net power.

Manufacturers of vehicles in respect of which this section applies shall apply to the Canadian Vehicle Manufacturers’ Association for the characters referred to in paragraphs 3(a) and (a.1) that uniquely identify the manufacturer and class of vehicle.

Despite subsections (1) to (11), every vehicle having a model year of 2009 or earlier shall comply with the requirements of this section as it read on the day before the day on which this subsection came into force.

Subsection.Text: The hydraulic brake system of a every passenger car, multi-purpose passenger vehicle, truck, bus, three-wheeled vehicle, motorcycle, trailer, and trailer converter dolly shall contain brake fluid that conforms to the requirements of Technical Standards Document No. 116, Motor Vehicle Brake Fluids (TSD 116), as amended from time to time.

A reference in TSD 116 to a standard published by ASTM that is set out in column 1 of the table to this subsection may be read as a reference to the standard set out opposite that standard in column 2 of the table.
